column8: Message
column9: Try This

column8: Meeting others is your key to happiness—really! The more people you meet, the more you’ll feel a sense of connection and belonging at UW. And it’s the first step to making friends.
column9: Go to three Dawg Daze events that interest you. Find someone friendly and introduce yourself. People all over campus are excited to welcome first year students.

column7: All the Time in the World?
column8: With just a few hours of classes a day, how will you spend your free time? The best way to fit in your coursework, fun, and self-care is to structure it.
column9: Create a weekly schedule. Include classes, time for study and your job, but also time for socializing and self-care. Leave room to tweak your schedule to meet academic demands and accommodate unexpected events.

column7: Find Your People, Make Your Place
column8: Student organizations, campus events, and volunteering are just some of the ways you can find community and build skills beyond the classroom.
column9: Look for engaging activities that also have a strong, welcoming community. A student organization, a performance group, or sports team is a place to start. You’ll make friends and learn and grow from the people around you.

column8: Studying well doesn’t always come naturally, but it’s not an impossible skill to master.
column9: Pro tips from UW Faculty: attend all classes, review lecture notes promptly, join a study group (meet 90 mins/week), and become comfortable asking for help. Try forming a study group or attending office hours—both are a great way to deepen your understanding of course material.

column8: Faced with your first college writing assignment or paper? The Odegaard Writing and Research Center (OWRC) can help.
column9: Bring a draft to the writing consultant at OWRC — make an appointment today!

column8: Need help clarifying interests and goals? Want more information on a course of study? Partner with a general or departmental adviser to shape your academic career!
column9: Drop in or make an appointment to see an adviser. Questions you could ask: How do I choose classes if I'm thinking about multiple majors? Are there ways to tell if a class will be good before enrolling?

column8: It's normal to feel anxious your first quarter. Thankfully, there are easy and constructive ways to help yourself feel better.
column9: Get outdoors, exercise, eat well, and get good sleep. Talk to supportive friends and family members. You can also try meditation or simple breathing exercises.
column14: Get Help at UW Health & Wellness
column16: Video: Students Talk about Mental Health at UW

column8: What intrigues you? What do you care about? How do you want to make a difference? Curiosity is at the heart of learning, so tune in and follow where it leads!
column9: Find issues you care about and then browse related suggestions or search for courses and see what speaks to you.

column8: The key to success, especially during finals, is to study on your own and with a study group. It’s not too late to get a group together.
column9: Talk to others in your class! Use your group to review lecture notes, predict test questions, and practice essay responses.

column8: Dining dollars dwindling? Coffee consuming cash? Now’s the time to get a handle on your finances.
column9: Track your spending for a week. Then create a realistic budget (see tips below).

column8: Finish the quarter strong by making healthy habits a priority. Research has shown that better sleep = better exam grades. Take care of yourself and your brain will thank you.
column9: Aim for 7-8 hours of sleep a night. Balance individual studying with group work. Take 10 minutes to recharge every hour. Snack smart for brain power. And when you’re done, celebrate!
column10: Sleep Linked to Higher Test Scores

column8: What are your hopes and aspirations for 2017? What did you learn in your first quarter at UW that you can build on?
column9: Set aside time for yourself — or ask a friend to join you — to take a look at the link below and choose two resolutions that speak to you.
column10: New Year’s Resolutions for College Students

column8: Develop your skills while making a difference in your community. Your passion and commitment are needed.
column9: Volunteer on MLK Day of Service. Learn more and reflect on your leadership skills at a fireside talk.

column8: Scholarships may still be available for this year, and many others offer funding next year for school and related activities.
column9: Search the scholarship database based on your interests and activities. Use the filters to find scholarships that apply to you.

column8: Many students who study abroad say it changed their lives, and sometimes their course of study. Interested? Browse the student study abroad stories below!
column9: Talk to upperclass people about their study abroad experiences to learn what might be in it for you. Or if you're ready to start planning, check out the Getting Started resource or start looking for a program.

column8: Want to explore an interest, gain practical experience, and add to your resume? Find an internship – or craft your own!
column9: Learn about internships, and reflect on what you want out of the experience. Use this knowledge to guide you as you explore.

column8: Thinking about courses for next quarter? Now is a great time to revisit plans you had when you arrived at UW. Have your interests changed? Are you drawn to something new?
column9: Browse department websites, talk with an adviser, and take courses that interest you. These steps can help you explore majors and potential back-ups. Use MyPlan to track your course options.
column16: U101: How to Choose a Major

column8: With dark skies, cold weather, and more time indoors, winter can impact your mental and physical health. Reach out if you're sad, rest if you're sick. Take steps to boost your winter wellness.
column9: Take owernship for your health and healthy habits — take the Healthy Huskies pledge! Prevent illness and improve your mood by exercising regularly, eating healthy, getting plenty of sleep, and keeping hydrated.
column12: Light Therapy for Seasonal Affective Disorder

column8: Say no to cramming and say yes to cardio! Prep smart for finals by planning your study strategy: solo review, time with study partners, and time for self-care.
column9: Check out the tips below and make a study plan. Strategizing now can help you decrease stress and better retain what you've learned.

column8: Viewed in the right light, challenges—even failure—can help you develop an attitude of healthy resilience.
column9: Learn the difference between a "fixed" vs. "growth" mindset. How can you apply these concepts to your own life? Learn about the efforts of the UW Relience Lab.

column8: Internships and summer jobs can help you gain experience for your resume and money for your bank account.
column9: For inspiration, check out 50 of the most interesting summer internships. See what Career & Internships Center events can help get you started.

column8: Want to add breadth and depth to your Husky Experience? Find people who will challenge and expand the way you think.
column9: Choose intriguing classes. Connect with instructors and peers—ask them about their research and ideas. Google your profs as a start!

column8: Anxious about an upcoming paper or project? Get expert advice at any stage.
column9: Chat with a librarian (real-time help 24/7). Make an appointment at a campus writing center, or browse great online resources.

column8: Practicing mindfulness can boost immunity, increase attention span, and decrease stress. And it's simple enough to do anywhere.
column9: Mindful breathing can help calm nerves. Close your eyes; take ten slow, deep breaths. Inhale through your nose; exhale through your mouth. Focus carefully on each breath.
column12: Video: UW students talk about mental health and resources

column7: Make the Most of Your Summer
column8: There are lots of ways to gain experience over the next few months. Having fun trying something new!
column9: Consider research, mentorship, or a unique summer job. Begin with the resources below, but also ask friends, family, and advisers, "What's the best summer you ever had?"

column8: Say no to cramming and say yes to cardio! Prep smart for finals by planning your study strategy: solo review, time with study partners, and time for self-care.
column9: Check out the tips below and make a study plan. Strategizing now can help you decrease stress and better retain what you've learned.

column8: You made it!! Take a moment to appreciate all the ways you've grown—in classes and beyond—during your first year at UW.
